ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
recorded lecture
live virtual lecture
Also virtual section
virtual discussion section

We had two recorded lectures per week. We also had one whole class live discussion per week, and one smaller section discussion every week. Each lecture, seminar, and large group discussion was 50 minutes to an hour. We were also expected to write weekly blog responses and do readings.
Each week, we would watch two prerecorded lectures, attend a virtual seminar, and participate in a virtual discussion section.
Recorded Lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Improved my critical reading, writing, and research skills. Most importantly, gained a deep insight into the different modes of cross-cultural exchange during the Middle Ages.

I learned a lot about how the middle ages actually worked, and also I learned a lot about the ways that the middle ages that are often presented to modern audiences are edited versions of a larger history.
I learned to be wary of reaching for the easy answer and to challenge generalizations. More than any other course I've taken this semester, this course encouraged me to think in more nuanced ways.
I was able to learn to think critically about history.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Too many meetings. We didn't need section.
Strength is the small numbers and accessibility of texts.

The expectations for the class were not always clear. While I appreciated the amount of freedom afforded to us with regards to our midterm and final, there were times in class where the reading we were expected to do was unclear or the framing of a question was confusing. However, I think a lot of the course confusion was related to being digital.

If you're interested in exploring the "other" and exclusion based on religious, ethnic, or gender affiliations, then I would highly recommend this course. I'd never explored these topics through the lens of the Middle Ages before; it was fascinating to dive into a time period that seems remote at first glance but actually grappled with many of the issues that we continue to grapple with today. The course does an excellent job of bringing in a variety of historical perspectives and texts, and I particularly looked forward to unpacking these in our discussion sections. At the same time, I sometimes wished our discussions could be more student-directed. Every discussion we had was led by a professor or TF, and although they encouraged us to bring up passages that interested us, I think the discussions often ended up reflecting their interests more than they reflected ours. I think it would have also helped if each week's topic had transitioned more clearly into the next; that would have given me more of a sense of the course's structure and how all the pieces fit together.
They did everything right. The option to choose how to present ones papers was very helpful as well. I was able to explore my writing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual lecture was great. Synchronous seminar with professors was a good balance. Improvement in providing breakout rooms

I think that the whole group discussions were not as helpful as the smaller seminar discussions. While they were useful for making sure everyone was on the same page (which I appreciated a lot), the large group discussions did not help me understand the topics as much as the seminar discussions. I loved my seminar. There was a good balance of speaking and hearing from my peers that helped me digest the readings and lectures well. I also think the smaller seminar allowed my group to develop a level of comfort that is difficult to achieve over zoom, especially in a large group setting.

We spent the first 20 minutes of our weekly seminar in breakout rooms and then came back to share what we'd discussed with the rest of the class. Since speaking out in a large Zoom meeting can be intimidating, this made it easier for everyone's ideas to be heard. I also liked that our lectures were prerecorded because this actually made it easier for me to take notes and absorb the material, and the fact that everyone had to respond to these lectures in a discussion post helped us to engage with the lectures.
The flexibility was amazing. The recorded lectures instead of meeting many times in the week was great. The ability to chose the format of exams was great as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Super nice professors, but boring
Yeah, very open approach to the middle ages
Yes! A very interesting, well-structured, and insightful course for anyone interested in learning more about the Middle Ages (without having any previous background about the period).

Yes. I think this class was an interesting and straightforward introduction to the middle ages. While the subject is complicated, my professors and teaching fellow were great at not making the material more complicated, and I saw their genuine interest in all of the topics we covered.
Absolutely take this course. I was worried because I thought it would be another boring course on white history again but I was completely wrong. I enjoyed this class so much.
